title: Loch Glass Walking Route

images.title: The "Pink Lodge", Loch Glass by Richard Webb, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The somewhat remote "Pink Lodge"at Loch Glass.

images.title: Richard Webb / Outflow, Loch Glass
images.caption: Outflow, Loch Glass. There was once a weir, but there seems to have been some restoration work here. The loch is a water source for Easter Ross.

images.title: sylvia duckworth / Wild Boar at Culzie
images.caption: Wild Boar at Culzie

images.title: Richard Webb / Loch Glass
images.caption: From the lochside track, looking towards Meall Mòr.

images.title: Richard Webb / Regenerating woods, Loch Glass
images.caption: Regenerating woods. Fenced in birchwood. Would regenerate a lot quicker if the ground was disturbed allowing good conditions for germination of the birches. A few pigs would do the trick and elsewhere in this area there are enclosures with pigs in them.

images.title: Richard Webb / Loch Glass
images.caption: The loch from Coire nan Laoigh on Ben Wyvis. The tidemark outline is due to the removal of a weir on the outflow.

description: This walk takes you along peaceful Loch Glass in the Scottish Highlands. You can follow a nice footpath along the western side of the loch, starting at the southern end where it meets with the River Glass. You'll pass the distinctive Pink House on the estate before coming to woodland around Culzie Lodge. Along the way there are good views of the nearby Ben Wyvis and the possibility of spotting some Wild Boar as well. You could extend the walk by heading north to visit the lovely Loch Morie .

details.subtitle: Dog Walking
details.content: The lochside paths and the surrounding forest trails are ideal for dog walking.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: To the south west there's Rogie Falls and Loch Achilty to explore. To the south there's the town of Dingwall where you can enjoy a walk along the old Dingwall Canal. It's a nice easy waterside walk with splendid views over the Cromarty Firth at the coastal end. Also nearby is the village of Strathpeffer where you can enjoy a circular walk to the ancient rocks at the Touchstone Maze, the splendid Cat's Back Ridge and the picturesque Loch Ussie. For more walking ideas in the area see the Scottish Highlands Walks page.
